## Table of Contents

Corporate and Unallocated and Other: Outside of 3M's reportable operating segments, 3M has Corporate and Unallocated and Other which are not reportable business segments as they do not meet the segment reporting criteria. Because Corporate and Unallocated and Other include a variety of miscellaneous items, they are subject to fluctuation on a quarterly and annual basis. Corporate and Unallocated and Other are presented separately in the preceding business segments table and in Note 22.

- Corporate and Unallocated operating income (loss) includes 'corporate special items' and 'other corporate expense-net'.
- Corporate special items include net costs for significant litigation impacting operating income (loss) associated with PFAS-related other environmental and Combat Arms Earplugs matters. In addition, during the voluntary chapter 11 bankruptcy period (which began in July 2022 and ended in June 2023), costs associated with the Aearo portion of respirator mask/asbestos matters were also included in corporate special items. Prior to the bankruptcy, costs associated with Combat Arms Earplugs matters were not included in the Corporate net costs for significant litigation special item, instead being reflected in the Safety and Industrial business segment. Corporate special items for the periods presented also include divestiture costs, gain on business divestitures, divestiture-related restructuring actions and Russia ex it charges/benefits. Divestiture costs include costs that were not eligible to be part of discontinued operations related to separating and divesting substantially an entire business segment of 3M following public announcement of its intended divestiture.
- Refer to the Certain amounts adjusted for special items - (non-GAAP measures) section for additional details on the impact of special items for additional information on the components of corporate special items. Corporate special item net costs decreased year-over-year in 2024, primarily due to lower net costs for significant litigation associated with Corporate and Unallocated. Corporate special item net costs increased year-over-year in 2023, primarily due to increased net costs for significant litigation as a result of pre-tax  charges of $10.3 billion and $4.2 billion in the second and third quarters of 2023 related to the PWS Settlement and the CAE Settlement, respectively (both discussed in Note 19), and lower gains on business divestitures.
- Other corporate expense-net includes certain enterprise and governance activities resulting in unallocated corporate costs and other activity and net costs that 3M may choose not to allocate directly to its business segments. Other corporate expense-net also includes costs previously allocated to Solventum prior to the Separation that were not eligible to be part of discontinued operations, commercial activity with Solventum postSeparation, and certain operations of the former Health Care business segment retained by 3M.
- Other corporate operating expenses, net, decreased year-over-year in 2024 primarily due to the extent of non-discontinued operationseligible former Solventum-allocated costs included in Corporate and Unallocated prior to Solventum's April 2024 Separation. Other corporate operating expenses, net, increased year-over-year in 2023 primarily due to higher restructuring charges (see Note 6).

## · Other:

- This category principally reflects activity associated with:
- Operations of businesses of the former Health Care segment divested prior to the Separation and therefore not reflected as discontinued operations within 3M's financial statements, along with limited-duration supply agreements with those previous divestitures.
- Transition arrangement agreements (e.g. fees charged by 3M, net of underlying costs) related to divested businesses, including those related to the Separation, as well as other applicable divestitures.
- Operating income categorized as "Other" decreased year-over-year in 2024 primarily due to the extent of transition arrangement income from divested businesses (and associated costs) largely related to Solventum, which separated in April 2024. Operating income categorized as "Other" decreased year-over-year in 2023 as a result of divestiture of the Food Safety Division and dental local anesthetic businesses (both formerly part of the "Other" category) and the extent of transition arrangement income from divested businesses other than Solventum.

questions.question: How did MMM's Corporate and Unallocated segment evolve across 2022 to 2024 in terms of net sales contribution and operating expense allocation, and what does this progression suggest about the company's approach to centralized cost management?
questions.answer: In 2022, MMM's Corporate and Unallocated segment primarily held shared assets like corporate headquarters, laboratories, and enterprise software systems, indicating a centralized approach to infrastructure. By 2023, the segment's net sales contribution was minimal at just $3 million, reflecting its role as a residual corporate entity rather than a revenue-generating division. In 2024, the segment's operating expenses were split between employee-related ($6 million) and asset-related/other costs ($14 million), totaling $20 million, a significant reduction from $238 million in 2023, driven largely by decreases in both categories. This progression suggests a strategic shift toward decentralizing previously centralized costs, with more expenses being directly attributed to operating segments, as seen in the substantial drop in the Corporate and Unallocated segment's expense burden.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: MMM(2022) → Corporate and Unallocated: The segment held shared assets such as corporate headquarters, labs, and software systems, indicating a centralized asset management model.
Hop 2: MMM(2023) → Corporate and Unallocated: The segment contributed only $3 million in net sales, reinforcing its role as a non-operational, corporate entity.

Hop 3: MMM(2024) → Corporate and Unallocated: The segment's operating expenses dropped from $238 million in 2023 to $20 million in 2024, with a clear breakdown into employee-related and asset-related costs.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text: Assets subject to attribution to business segments largely include accounts receivable; inventories; property, plant and equipment; goodwill; intangible assets; and certain limited other assets. All other items are reflected in Corporate and Unallocated. Accounts receivable and inventory are attributed based on underlying sales or activity. Property, plant and equipment are attributed to a particular business segment based on that item's primary user while certain items such as corporate-shared headquarters/administrative centers, laboratories, distribution centers and enterprise software systems are reflected in Corporate and Unallocated. Intangible assets and goodwill are largely directly associated with a particular reporting unit and attributed on that basis. Business segment depreciation reflected above is based on the underlying usage of assets (while the particular asset itself may be entirely reflected within a different business segment's asset balance as its primary user). This depreciation also includes allocated depreciation associated with a number of the assets reflected in Corporate and Unallocated as described above.

questions.question: How did MMM's deferred tax asset related to Advanced Payments change from 2022 ($286M) to 2023 ($76M), and then to 2024 ($14M), and what does this 3-year trajectory suggest about the company's tax planning or payment structuring strategies?
questions.answer: MMM's deferred tax asset associated with Advanced Payments declined sharply from $286 million in 2022 to $76 million in 2023, and then to just $14 million in 2024. This consistent and steep reduction indicates a strategic shift in how MMM is managing or recognizing advanced payments for tax purposes, potentially signaling a move away from deferring tax liabilities linked to this category or a structural change in customer payment terms.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MMM](2022) → [Advanced Payments]: In 2022, MMM reported a deferred tax asset of $286 million related to Advanced Payments, indicating a significant tax deferral impact from this category.

Hop 2: [MMM](2023) → [Advanced Payments]: By 2023, the deferred tax asset tied to Advanced Payments had dropped to $76 million, a decrease of over 70%, suggesting a major change in the company’s treatment or volume of advanced payments.

Hop 3: [MMM](2024) → [Advanced Payments]: In 2024, the deferred tax asset for Advanced Payments was further reduced to just $14 million, continuing the downward trend and reinforcing a long-term shift in tax planning or revenue recognition strategy.

questions.question: With the April 2024 separation of its Health Care business, how did MMM's Transportation and Electronics segment evolve from 2022 to 2024 in terms of sales performance, organic growth trajectory, and strategic positioning as one of the company's three remaining core segments?
questions.answer: In 2022, MMM's Transportation and Electronics segment reported $9,769 million in net sales and $2,008 million in operating income, showing relatively stable performance compared to earlier years. By 2023, the segment experienced a 3.5% decline in organic sales, despite minor growth contributions from acquisitions (0.7%), resulting in an overall 4.5% decline in total sales, signaling emerging market or demand pressures. In 2024, following the separation of the Health Care business, MMM restructured its reporting segments, positioning Transportation and Electronics as one of only three continuing business segments, emphasizing its strategic importance. This evolution shows a shift from a relatively stable contributor in 2022 to a segment facing organic headwinds in 2023, and ultimately becoming a core pillar of MMM's post-2024 portfolio following the strategic refocusing of the company.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: MMM(2022) → Transportation and Electronics: $9,769 million in net sales and $2,008 million in operating income, indicating a stable and significant contributor to MMM's overall performance.
Hop 2: MMM(2023) → Transportation and Electronics: Organic sales declined by 3.5%, with total sales down 4.5% after accounting for divestitures and translation effects, showing emerging pressures.

Hop 3: MMM(2024) → Transportation and Electronics: Segment retained strategic prominence as one of only three continuing business segments after the April 2024 Health Care separation, signaling its central role in MMM's future.

hop_3_rel.chunk_text:
General Employees' Stock Purchase Plan (GESPP): As of December 31, 2024, shareholders have approved 60 million shares for issuance under the Company's GESPP. Substantially all employees are eligible to participate in the plan. Participants are granted options at 85% of market value at the date of grant. There are no GESPP shares under option at the beginning or end of each year because options are granted on the first business day and exercised on the last business day of the same month.

The weighted-average fair value per option granted during 2024, 2023 and 2022 was $16.76, $15.77 and $21.20, respectively. The fair value of GESPP options was based on the 15% purchase price discount. The Company recognized compensation expense for GESPP options of $12 million, $21 million, and $31 million in 2024, 2023 and 2022, respectively.

## NOTE 22. Business Segments and Geographic Information

3M's businesses are organized, managed and internally grouped into segments based on differences in markets, products, technologies and services. 3M manages its continuing operations in three business segments: Safety and Industrial; Transportation and Electronics; and Consumer. 3M's three business segments bring together common or related 3M technologies, enhancing the development of innovative products and services and providing for efficient sharing of business resources. On April 1, 2024, 3M completed the previously announced separation of its Health Care business as a separate public company, Solventum (see Note 2 for additional information). 3M is an integrated enterprise characterized by substantial intersegment cooperation, cost allocations and inventory transfers. Therefore, management does not represent that these segments, if operated independently, would report the operating income information shown.

3M discloses business segment operating income (loss) as its measure of segment profit/loss, reconciled to both total 3M operating income (loss) and income before taxes. Business segment operating income (loss) excludes certain expenses and income that are not allocated to business segments (as described below in 'Corporate and Unallocated and Other'). Business segment disclosures consider information used by/provided to 3M's chief operating decision maker (CODM). For 3M, the CODM is the chief executive officer. The CODM uses business segment operating income (loss) to allocate resources to segments in the planning and forecasting process along with periodic ongoing reviews of results and overall market activity.

3M made certain changes to the composition of segment information reviewed by 3M's CODM effective in the second quarter of 2024 largely as a result of the separation of Solventum and changes within its business segments effective in the first quarter of 2024. Accordingly, information provided herein reflects the impact of these changes for all applicable periods presented.

Effective in the second quarter of 2024, this change included the following:

Elimination of former Health Care business segment

- The former Health Care business segment was eliminated in the second quarter of 2024 in connection with the separation of Solventum and reflection of its historical net income and applicable assets and liabilities included in the Separation as discontinued operations within 3M's financial statements.

Addition of 'Other' and update to 'Corporate and Unallocated'

- 3M added the 'Other' category of information as a result of the Separation. It principally reflects:
- Transition arrangement agreements (e.g. fees charged by 3M, net of underlying costs) related to divested businesses, including those related to the Separation, as well as other applicable divestitures.
- Operations of businesses of the former Health Care segment divested prior to the Separation and therefore not reflected as discontinued operations within 3M's financial statements, along with limited-duration supply agreements with those previous divestitures.
- Activity included in 3M's existing 'Corporate and Unallocated' was updated primarily to additionally reflect:
- Removal of costs related to separating and divesting Solventum that were eligible to be part of discontinued operations.
- Commercial activity with Solventum post-Separation and certain operations of the former Health Care business segment retained by 3M.
- Costs previously allocated to Solventum prior to the Separation that were not eligible to be part of discontinued operations other than those beginning in the first quarter of 2024 included in 'Other' associated with transition arrangement activity for which 3M began to charge fees in April 2024.

questions.question: How did MMM's sales in the Advanced Materials and Industries Segment evolve from 2022 to 2024, given the segment's reported sales of $9.2 billion in 2022, $9.8 billion in 2023, and $10.5 billion in 2024, and what does this progression indicate about MMM's strategic positioning in high-performance materials?
questions.answer: MMM's sales in the Advanced Materials and Industries Segment increased steadily over the three-year period, rising from $9.2 billion in 2022 to $9.8 billion in 2023, and further to $10.5 billion in 2024. This consistent growth reflects a compound annual growth rate (CAGR) of approximately 3.4%, indicating MMM's strengthening market position and ongoing strategic focus on high-performance materials. The upward trajectory suggests sustained demand for the segment’s products and MMM’s ability to capitalize on industrial and technological trends through this business unit.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MMM](2022) → [Advanced Materials and Industries Segment]: MMM reported $9.2 billion in sales from this segment in 2022, establishing a baseline for its performance in high-performance materials.
Hop 2: [MMM](2023) → [Advanced Materials and Industries Segment]: Sales increased to $9.8 billion in 2023, showing a $600 million year-over-year growth and signaling early momentum in the segment.

Hop 3: [MMM](2024) → [Advanced Materials and Industries Segment]: The segment reached $10.5 billion in sales in 2024, continuing the upward trend and reinforcing MMM’s strategic emphasis on advanced materials.

questions.question: How did 3M's financial impact from divestiture-related restructuring actions evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this 3-year progression reveal about the company's divestiture strategy execution?
questions.answer: In 2022, 3M reported a $0.05 per diluted share impact from divestiture-related restructuring actions. By 2023, this impact had ceased, with no such charge reflected in the earnings table. In 2024, the company noted a decrease in corporate special item net costs, partly due to lower divestiture-related restructuring actions. This trend indicates that 3M's divestiture strategy matured over time, with initial restructuring costs in 2022 tapering off by 2023 and further reducing in 2024, suggesting the completion or stabilization of major divestiture-related transitions.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: [MMM](2022) → [Divestiture-related restructuring actions]: Reports $0.05 per diluted share impact from divestiture-related restructuring actions.

Hop 2: [MMM](2023) → [Divestiture-related restructuring actions]: No direct charge for divestiture-related restructuring actions appears in the earnings per share breakdown, indicating a reduction or cessation of such costs.

Hop 3: [MMM](2024) → [Divestiture-related restructuring actions]: Notes a decrease in corporate special item net costs, partly due to reduced divestiture-related restructuring actions, showing the trend continued downward.

Corporate and Unallocated net operating loss increased in 2021 when compared to 2020 primarily related to the pre-tax gain of $387 million included in special items in 2020 as a result of 3M's divestiture of its drug delivery business (see Note 3 for additional details).

## Special Items

Refer to the Certain amounts adjusted for special items - (non-GAAP measures) section and Note 5 for additional details on the impact of significant litigation-related charges/benefits, gain/loss on sale of businesses, and divestiture-related restructuring actions that are reflected in Corporate and Unallocated.

## Other Corporate Expense - Net

Other corporate operating expenses decreased in 2021 when compared to 2020. The decrease was primarily due to a $91 million pre-tax benefit from the impact of the favorable decision of the Brazilian Supreme Court in the second quarter of 2021 regarding the calculation of past social taxes, continued lower overall corporate staff spending and first quarter 2020 charges related to equity securities (as discussed in the 'Assets and Liabilities that are Measured at Fair Value on a Nonrecurring Basis' section of Note 15), partially offset by increased legal and reserve adjustment costs.

hop_2_rel.chunk_text:
## Table of Contents

Corporate and Unallocated and Other: Outside of 3M's reportable operating segments, 3M has Corporate and Unallocated and Other which are not reportable business segments as they do not meet the segment reporting criteria. Because Corporate and Unallocated and Other include a variety of miscellaneous items, they are subject to fluctuation on a quarterly and annual basis. Corporate and Unallocated and Other are presented separately in the preceding business segments table and in Note 22.

- Corporate and Unallocated operating income (loss) includes 'corporate special items' and 'other corporate expense-net'.
- Corporate special items include net costs for significant litigation impacting operating income (loss) associated with PFAS-related other environmental and Combat Arms Earplugs matters. In addition, during the voluntary chapter 11 bankruptcy period (which began in July 2022 and ended in June 2023), costs associated with the Aearo portion of respirator mask/asbestos matters were also included in corporate special items. Prior to the bankruptcy, costs associated with Combat Arms Earplugs matters were not included in the Corporate net costs for significant litigation special item, instead being reflected in the Safety and Industrial business segment. Corporate special items for the periods presented also include divestiture costs, gain on business divestitures, divestiture-related restructuring actions and Russia ex it charges/benefits. Divestiture costs include costs that were not eligible to be part of discontinued operations related to separating and divesting substantially an entire business segment of 3M following public announcement of its intended divestiture.
- Refer to the Certain amounts adjusted for special items - (non-GAAP measures) section for additional details on the impact of special items for additional information on the components of corporate special items. Corporate special item net costs decreased year-over-year in 2024, primarily due to lower net costs for significant litigation associated with Corporate and Unallocated. Corporate special item net costs increased year-over-year in 2023, primarily due to increased net costs for significant litigation as a result of pre-tax  charges of $10.3 billion and $4.2 billion in the second and third quarters of 2023 related to the PWS Settlement and the CAE Settlement, respectively (both discussed in Note 19), and lower gains on business divestitures.
- Other corporate expense-net includes certain enterprise and governance activities resulting in unallocated corporate costs and other activity and net costs that 3M may choose not to allocate directly to its business segments. Other corporate expense-net also includes costs previously allocated to Solventum prior to the Separation that were not eligible to be part of discontinued operations, commercial activity with Solventum postSeparation, and certain operations of the former Health Care business segment retained by 3M.
- Other corporate operating expenses, net, decreased year-over-year in 2024 primarily due to the extent of non-discontinued operationseligible former Solventum-allocated costs included in Corporate and Unallocated prior to Solventum's April 2024 Separation. Other corporate operating expenses, net, increased year-over-year in 2023 primarily due to higher restructuring charges (see Note 6).

## · Other:

- This category principally reflects activity associated with:
- Operations of businesses of the former Health Care segment divested prior to the Separation and therefore not reflected as discontinued operations within 3M's financial statements, along with limited-duration supply agreements with those previous divestitures.
- Transition arrangement agreements (e.g. fees charged by 3M, net of underlying costs) related to divested businesses, including those related to the Separation, as well as other applicable divestitures.
- Operating income categorized as "Other" decreased year-over-year in 2024 primarily due to the extent of transition arrangement income from divested businesses (and associated costs) largely related to Solventum, which separated in April 2024. Operating income categorized as "Other" decreased year-over-year in 2023 as a result of divestiture of the Food Safety Division and dental local anesthetic businesses (both formerly part of the "Other" category) and the extent of transition arrangement income from divested businesses other than Solventum.

questions.question: How did MMM's expense allocation to Corporate and Unallocated evolve from 2022 to 2024, and what does the 3-year trajectory suggest about the company's cost management and strategic realignment efforts?
questions.answer: In 2022, MMM described its expense allocation methodology, noting that Corporate and Unallocated included enterprise-wide assets and costs such as shared headquarters, labs, and software systems. By 2023, the Corporate and Unallocated segment reported only $4 million in net sales, indicating minimal direct revenue generation from this segment. In 2024, MMM provided explicit operating expense figures, showing that Corporate and Unallocated carried $20 million in total operating expenses—$6 million in employee-related costs and $14 million in asset-related and other expenses. This represents a significant reduction from 2023, where the segment had $238 million in total operating expenses (including $171 million employee-related and $67 million asset-related). The 91.6% drop in total operating expenses over the two-year period suggests a deliberate strategic realignment to reduce overhead and centralize cost efficiency.
reasoning_steps: Hop 1: MMM(2022) → Corporate and Unallocated: Describes allocation methodology, noting that shared infrastructure and enterprise systems are housed in this segment.
Hop 2: MMM(2023) → Corporate and Unallocated: Reports only $4 million in net sales for this segment, indicating it is not revenue-generating and primarily cost-focused.
Hop 3: MMM(2024) → Corporate and Unallocated: Explicitly reports $20 million in total operating expenses, a dramatic drop from the $238 million in 2023, showing significant cost reduction.

hop_1_rel.chunk_text: Assets subject to attribution to business segments largely include accounts receivable; inventories; property, plant and equipment; goodwill; intangible assets; and certain limited other assets. All other items are reflected in Corporate and Unallocated. Accounts receivable and inventory are attributed based on underlying sales or activity. Property, plant and equipment are attributed to a particular business segment based on that item's primary user while certain items such as corporate-shared headquarters/administrative centers, laboratories, distribution centers and enterprise software systems are reflected in Corporate and Unallocated. Intangible assets and goodwill are largely directly associated with a particular reporting unit and attributed on that basis. Business segment depreciation reflected above is based on the underlying usage of assets (while the particular asset itself may be entirely reflected within a different business segment's asset balance as its primary user). This depreciation also includes allocated depreciation associated with a number of the assets reflected in Corporate and Unallocated as described above.

questions.question: How did 3M's deferred tax asset related to Advanced Payments evolve from 2022 through 2024, and what does this trend indicate about the company's tax planning or operational strategies involving advanced payments?
questions.answer: In 2022, 3M reported $286 million in deferred tax assets related to Advanced Payments. By 2023, this figure dropped significantly to $76 million, and in 2024, it further declined to just $14 million. This consistent decline over the three-year period indicates a strategic reduction in the use of advanced payments for tax deferral purposes or a shift in the company's operational or financial planning strategies that reduced reliance on such mechanisms.

Hop 2: [MMM](2023) → [Advanced Payments]: Deferred tax asset of $76 million
Hop 3: [MMM](2024) → [Advanced Payments]: Deferred tax asset of $14 million
